column4: I have installed Ubuntu on my Dell laptop, and it seems to work fine. However, the laptop fan is now permanently on (making quite a noise) as compared with fairly un-noticeable fan usage when I boot into Windows. Is there something wrong?
websearch for the model in conjuction with ubuntu, there may be a bug report or guide

I've googled my laptop fan issue, and discovered several posts on various forums confirming that others have experienced this. But it doesn't seem specific to my own laptop; many other get this too. Is it that Ubuntu simply doesn't control the fan at all and leaves it on?
in some cases yes, seems you may need some boot options or somesuch, dellare very documented so you may find guides
one is older than the other. you can remove thee -11 kernel if you do not use it
edit /etc/default/grub    then run: sudo update-grub
assuming karmic is you release
when you want to detatch the device, do you just yank it out or do you safetly remove the device, then unplug?
what file system is it using?
NTFS? FAT32? Ext2/3/4 ??
It says msdos under properties. How do I check?
'W95 FAT32 (LBA)'
oh jeez
I suggest you fsck the partition, may help
What does fsck do exactly?
its like chkdsk in windows
If the drive shows up as /media/HD-CUE2 then I can just fsck /media/HD-CUE2?
you need to unmount the partition first
fsck says 'Bad short file name (\031\000\000\000B \000I.\000n\000).', and gives options to drop file, rename etc. What is this doing/what should I do?
Fat32 isn't very robust. I suggest you chkdsk in Windows
With the hope that chkdsk might do what?
repair the file system. Sounds like it's not being used correctly (afe removal in the OS before pysical removal)
Ok. I will reboot into windows and try chkdsk, and if that doesn't do the trick, give PhotoRec a try.
tell your buddy to get a backup in place
